Graphical abstract The design strategy and mechanism of action of catalysts are explored to enhance the efficiency of coal conversion and help the development of clean energy. Coal direct liquefaction technology is a crucial contemporary coal chemical technology for efficient and clean use of coal resources. The development of direct coal liquefaction technology and the promotion of alternative energy sources are important measures to guarantee energy security and economic security. However, several challenges need to be addressed, including low conversion rate, inadequate oil yield, significant coking, demanding reaction conditions, and high energy consumption. Extensive research has been conducted on these issues, but further exploration is required in certain aspects such as pyrolysis of macromolecules during the liquefaction process, hydrogen activation, catalysts’ performance and stability, solvent hydrogenation, as well as interactions between free radicals to understand their mechanisms better. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the design strategy for efficient catalysts in coal liquefaction, encompassing the mechanism of coal liquefaction, catalyst construction, and enhancement of catalytic conversion efficiency. It serves as a comprehensive guide for further research endeavors. Firstly, it systematically summarizes the conversion mechanism of direct coal liquefaction, provides detailed descriptions of various catalyst design strategies, and especially outlines the catalytic mechanism. Furthermore, it addresses the challenges and prospects associated with constructing efficient catalysts for direct coal liquefaction based on an understanding of their action mechanisms. Keywords Direct coal liquefaction Catalysts Mechanism of action Solvent hydrogenation 1 Introduction As the issue of global warming becomes increasingly prominent, the proportion of direct coal combustion is expected to gradually decline, while cleaner and more efficient methods of utilizing coal are anticipated to gain mainstream acceptance. The utilization of coal can be categorized into two primary domains: direct combustion and conversion. Direct combustion is primarily employed in industrial boilers, thermal power generation, and residential heating, whereas conversion encompasses coal gasification, coal liquefaction, and coal chemistry with the objective of producing cleaner gaseous or liquid fuels as well as high value-added chemicals through efficient conversion processes [1–4]. Direct coal liquefaction (DCL) technology represents one approach towards achieving clean and efficient utilization of coal resources. Currently, the predominant application for direct liquefaction involves oil production as a substitute for petroleum, hence it is also referred to as Coal-to-Liquids (CTL) technology [5–7]. The concept of directly converting coal into liquids was first introduced by Burgess, a Nobel Prize-winning chemist from German in 1913, since then it has undergone gradual development [8–11]. Fig. 1 (a) provides a historical overview of the direct liquefaction process for coal. Coal, a significant alternative to oil, is actively seeking innovation and technological advancements for its cleaner utilization. Coal liquefaction is anticipated to emerge as a prominent technology for supplying liquid fuels for transportation [12–15]. With over a century of development, direct coal liquefaction can be broadly categorized into two types [16]. The single-stage process is one in which coal is heated and treated directly in a liquefaction reaction using only one reaction temperature to produce a liquid product. During the single-stage process, the coal's structure is fractured and reorganized, resulting in the production of highly functional, high-molecular-weight substances. These substances are frequently challenging to process using conventional methods and are prone to aggregation, which can give rise to product stability issues. The single-stage process involves delivering distillate through a main reactor or reactors operating in series under identical conditions. This approach enables the direct conversion of coal into liquid fuels, offering an alternative energy source to petroleum along with high-quality transportation fuels and diverse chemical feedstocks. Nevertheless, this may prove problematic for lower-rank coals, as at elevated reaction temperatures, disparate types of bonds may be disrupted, some of which hydrogenate too slowly to effectively capture the free radicals formed. Moreover, their coupling reactions tend to diminish liquefaction yields. Furthermore, the high capital and operational costs associated with the single-stage liquefaction process hinder its competitiveness against. Moreover, the coal conversion efficiency of this process remains relatively low necessitating further enhancements to increase both coal conversion and liquid yields. Therefore, optimization of all aspects of the single-stage liquefaction process is essential, including enhancement of catalysts' efficiency, development of more efficient liquefaction reactors and slurry preheaters, as well as implementation of effective CO2 management and control/utilization strategies. These measures will significantly improve overall efficiency and economic viability. The two-stage process involves the sequential operation of two reactor stages, each operating under distinct conditions (two reaction temperature bands), to produce products. The initial stage of the process entails the dissolution of coal at elevated temperatures, resulting in the generation of highly functional coal fragments. Subsequently, the product is upgraded at lower temperatures through the addition of catalysts, which facilitate the reduction of functional groups, hydrogenation, and molecular weight reduction. The implementation of this method has the dual benefit of enhancing the selectivity of the product and reducing the concentration of impurities, including sulfur and nitrogen, in the liquid fuel obtained through hydrotreating. This, in turn, results in an improvement in the purity of the product. Through this dual processing method, carbon atoms in coal are more efficiently utilized, leading to increased conversion rates and reduced resource wastage. Catalyst selection is tailored to specific stage requirements, minimizing catalyst usage and lowering costs. The single-stage coal direct liquefaction process is relatively straightforward to operate and requires minimal initial investment. However, the conversion rate is relatively low, the process is not particularly adaptable to different coal types, and the liquid fuel produced contains high levels of sulfur and nitrogen impurities, which increases the long-term operating costs. In contrast, although the two-stage process has higher equipment investment, maintenance costs, and a more complex operational structure, it has a high conversion rate, which is highly adaptable to coal types and effectively reduces the sulfur and nitrogen impurity content in the liquid fuel by hydrotreating, thus improving the fuel quality and the economy of long-term operation [17,18]. Concurrently, both processes are constrained by the availability of suitable catalysts. Fig. 1(b) compares the advantages and disadvantages of the two processes and summarizes the types of catalysts applicable to the different processes. Suitable catalysts for single-stage processes: synthetic high-efficiency iron-based catalysts, e.g. FeOOH, and Mo-based catalysts, e.g. nanoscale molybdenum trioxide (high activity and simple operation). Suitable catalysts for two-stage processes: solid acid catalysts, and composite catalysts such as Ni-Mo, Co-Mo, Fe-Mo, etc. (relatively complex, but with high conversion and product quality). In general, single-stage processes favor the use of highly active, simple-to-operate catalysts, whereas two-stage processes may necessitate a more intricate combination of catalysts to achieve enhanced conversion efficiency and a superior quality end product. In practice, the selection of a catalyst must also take into account factors such as cost, stability, regeneration capability, and compatibility with specific coal types and process conditions. Therefore, continuous research efforts aim to develop more efficient catalysts that enhance reaction activity and selectivity while reducing costs. Notably, these processes have shifted focus towards catalyst utilization and development over time; transitioning from high reaction pressures up to 70 MPa towards more moderate reaction conditions has resulted in improved oil yields and significant cost reductions for coal liquefaction [1,12,16–21]. Many efforts have been devoted to the development of coal liquefaction technology, both domestically and internationally, with a particular focus on cost reduction and efficiency improvement [22–25]. The advancement of coal direct liquefaction technology has also led to significant progress in catalyst research and development [26–32]. This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent advancements in catalysts used for coal direct liquefaction technology. By providing an overview of coal liquefaction catalysts, as shown in Fig. 2 , they can be categorized into the following groups based on their active elements: firstly, iron-based catalysts including synthetic and natural pyrite, iron sulphate, synthetic iron oxides and hydroxides, as well as iron-containing compounds; secondly, Mo, Ni, Co hydrogenation catalysts including their oxides, sulphides, metal salts, and organic complexes; thirdly acidic catalysts such as non-ferrous halides like Zn, Sn, and so on; fourthly composite catalysts including typical Ni-Mo, Co-Mo, or other two or even three element composite systems; fifthly other types of catalysts. These catalysts play crucial roles in promoting reaction rates during direct coal liquefaction process while enhancing product selectivity and improving overall efficiency. Furthermore, this review also addresses aspects related to the stability, selectivity and regeneration of these catalytic materials. The insights provided herein can serve as valuable background knowledge for future research endeavors focused on coal liquefaction catalysis. 2 Principles of direct coal liquefaction The investigation of natural and synthetic hydrocarbons, as well as fuels derived from coal, oil, and natural gas, constitutes a crucial field in contemporary chemical manufacturing with a particular emphasis on their H/C atomic ratios [26,30]. Coal liquefaction is aimed at producing substitutes for petroleum distillate fuels with atomic ratios between 1.8 and 2.5, with the specific objective of producing, for example, petrol and diesel fuels. Coal liquefaction aims to produce substitutes for petroleum distillate fuels with atomic ratios ranging from 1.8 to 2.5, specifically representing the production of gasoline and diesel fuels [33–35]. Fig. 3 illustrates the chemical process involved in direct coal liquefaction [1,18,36]. Unlike petroleum, coal is a complex polymer characterized by condensed aromatic rings and molecular weights varying between 5000 and 10,000. Its aryl nuclei typically contain alkyl, carboxyl, carbonyl, phenol, thiol, thiophene, amine, indole, and pyridine groups [37,38]. The interactions among these macromolecules within coal such as aromatic stacking hydrogen bonding acid-base reactions and donor–acceptor interactions significantly influence its properties and reactivity. Consequently, disrupting these macromolecular interactions becomes essential for converting coal into soluble solvents during liquefaction [39,40]. The liquefaction process commences with the thermal cracking or hydrogenation of the weakest bonds in coal, resulting in the formation of smaller aromatic units that can exist as liquids or be soluble. The remaining coal molecules that resist liquefaction either aggregate into larger structures or convert into smaller gas molecules. Ultimately, the small organic molecules resulting from cracking are ultimately recombined to form more valuable liquid fuels and chemicals [41,42]. This transformation can be expedited by the use of a catalyst [43–46]. Manipulating various conditions such as temperature, pressure, solvent, and catalyst allows for precise control over pyrolysis, dissolution, cracking, and recombination processes. This control governs both the type and yield of end products [47,48]. Solvents that provide hydrogen play a crucial role by facilitating the dissolution of coal's macromolecules through breaking weaker bonds and preventing recondensation of smaller molecules. Some fragments are stabilized by hydrogen produced during coal pyrolysis while others rely on external hydrogen sources present in solvents and atmospheres [49–51]. If there is insufficient hydrogen to stabilize radicals within the system, they tend to combine and potentially form higher molecular weight semi-cokes or coke [51–53]. Catalyst can restore the dehydrogenated solvent's capacity for hydrogenation by rehydrogenating it [46–53]. Consequently, this catalytic process effectively breaks down coal's large molecular structure into liquid compounds with lower molecular weights thereby enhancing yields from low molecular weight fractions. In the context of direct coal liquefaction, the selection of suitable solvents assumes significant importance with regard to the enhancement of liquefaction performance, particularly in view of the fact that a variety of catalysts are involved. Firstly, the hydrogen donor capacity of the solvent is of paramount importance for the direct coal liquefaction reaction. The selection of solvents with a higher hydrogen donor capacity can provide a greater number of hydrogen atoms, which can prompt the catalyst to accelerate the reaction between hydrogen and free radicals generated from coal cracking. This results in an improvement in reaction efficiency and product distribution. Secondly, solubility and dispersibility are essential for effective dissolution of the coal and liquefaction products, as well as for ensuring their complete mixing with the catalyst, which is crucial for the efficiency of the reaction. The solubility of the solvent also affects the distribution of the product; thus, it is necessary to select the appropriate solvent according to the desired product. Thirdly, the solvent should demonstrate high thermal and chemical stability, and should remain stable under conditions of high temperature and high pressure without undergoing decomposition or reaction. This guarantees the manageability and reliability of the reaction. Ultimately, the solvent with the lowest cost and the most accessible source is the most viable for practical implementation. The appropriate solvent should be selected according to the specific reaction conditions and requirements. Furthermore, the impact of diverse solvents on the efficacy of a given reaction can be assessed through theoretical calculations, thereby aiding the selection and optimization of solvents. 3 Principle of action of direct coal liquefaction catalysts The process of coal liquefaction is a complex reaction process that involves reactants in both the dissolved and micellar solid states. These reactants must be reacted by means of a catalyst and hydrogen or a hydrogen-supplying solvent [46,54]. The role of the catalyst is to adsorb the reactants on the active site, causing them to react, and to release the products by desorption after the reaction (Fig. 4 a) [55,56]. Concurrently, the effects of catalysts on the hydrogen transfer pathway vary. To illustrate, the influence of solvents on coal conversion and oil production was found to be diminished when Fe-based catalysts were present. In contrast, the hydrogen transfer effect of the solvent was found to be enhanced under Ni-based catalysts. The primary hydrogen transfer pathway is the hydrogen-solvent-coal pathway. This phenomenon is primarily attributed to the high hydrogenation activity of Ni-based catalysts, which facilitates solvent hydrogen transfer from non-hydrogen donor aromatic compounds to the coal. The primary hydrogen transfer pathway is through direct hydrogen-radical binding, whereby the molecular hydrogen is activated to form free radicals generated by coal pyrolysis. In contrast, Ni-based catalysts demonstrate a more pronounced hydrogen transfer effect from the solvent. The primary hydrogen transfer pathway involves the transfer of gaseous hydrogen into the solvent, which then transfers the hydrogen into the coal. This suggests that Ni-based catalysts facilitate not only the activation of molecular hydrogen, but also the transfer of hydrogen from the solvent. In the presence of iron-based catalysts, the hydrogenation, ring-opening, and side-chain breaking reactions of DHA accounted for approximately 35% of the total hydrogen consumption. In contrast, the use of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (THN) as the solvent resulted in a significant reduction in the hydrogenation and ring-opening reactions, accounting for only approximately 4% of the total hydrogen consumption. This observation suggests that THN facilitated the transfer of hydrogen to the free radicals generated by coal cracking (Fig. 4b). These findings offer crucial insights into the fundamental principles governing the role of catalysts in direct liquefaction processes. Since coal consists of large molecules interacting with each other, these interactions greatly influence its properties and reactivity [57,58]. Therefore, optimization of solvent and catalyst interactions in the direct liquefaction of coal is essential to improve the quality and yield of the liquid product. Catalysts play a crucial role in this process as they induce hydrogenolysis reactions of coal molecules, cracking large molecules into smaller aromatic units while increasing liquid hydrocarbon yield [44,59]. Additionally, catalysts promote hydrogenation of liquid products by saturating unsaturated bonds and improving product quality through synergistic processes such as dissolution, pyrolysis, and acceptance of pyrolysis [60,61]. The conversion of asphaltenes and pre-asphaltenes represents a significant step in the pursuit of increased oil production rates. Catalysts facilitate the cracking of large molecular compounds in asphaltenes into smaller molecular compounds, including hydrocarbons and aromatic hydrocarbons. These cracking products are highly flammable and volatile. Secondly, catalysts also catalyze the dehydrogenation reaction in asphaltenes, removing hydrogen atoms from them, thereby reducing molecular weight and viscosity, and improving the fluidity and treatability of oil. Furthermore, catalysts can facilitate the removal of heteroatoms, such as sulfur and nitrogen, from asphaltenes. This reduces the heteroatom content of the oil and helps to reduce the contamination and corrosiveness of the oil. Finally, catalysts can promote cracking and restructuring reactions in asphaltenes. This rearranging and grouping of the carbon chains forms a molecular structure that is more conducive to combustion and processing. The use of catalysts allows for the absorption of asphaltene molecules, facilitating the reduction of the activation energy of the reaction through the provision of specific active sites (e.g., acidic, metal, and redox sites). For instance, the cleavage of asphaltene molecules into smaller hydrocarbon molecules can be achieved through the presence of an acidic catalyst. Additionally, the conversion of unsaturated bonds in asphaltenes to saturated bonds by hydrogenation, enabled by metal catalysts, can reduce molecular complexity. Furthermore, catalysts selectively promote desired reactions during coal liquefaction while inhibiting side reactions and improving product selectivity. Examples encompass the hydrogenation of aromatic rings and radicals, cleavage and hydrocracking reactions involving aryl alkyl bonds and aromatic rings, as well as the hydrogenolysis elimination of aromatic hydrocarbons to reduce heteroatom content such as oxygen, sulfur, and nitrogen in the resulting product [62]. Additionally, these catalysts facilitate the hydrogenation of liquid products by saturating unsaturated bonds and enhancing the quality of hydrocarbon products. Furthermore, they exhibit synergistic interactions with liquid products through dissolution, pyrolysis processes, and acceptance of pyrolysis to maintain a conducive liquid-phase environment that promotes reactions. Secondly, catalysts selectively promote desired reactions during coal liquefaction while inhibiting side reactions and improving product selectivity [63]. Catalysts play a pivotal role in coal liquefaction. However, empirical evidence has demonstrated that carbonaceous materials, poisoning, pyrolysis, and metal deposition can lead to the deactivation of certain catalysts [64,65]. Conventional catalysts face challenges in achieving complete surface accessibility due to the presence of high molecular weight asphaltene compounds in coal or petroleum residues. Moreover, loaded catalysts indirectly impact the coal liquefaction process as macromolecules are inaccessible to the catalyst's surface. Therefore, a promising research direction involves transforming the catalyst into a dispersed phase to generate small non-porous particles that offer a larger specific surface area for active hydrogen generation [66,67]. Research has been conducted on modifying iron-based catalysts, with a focus on creating non-stoichiometric ratios of sulphates that can adsorb onto the surface of iron oxides. This is achieved through treatment with sulphuric acid or by precipitation in the presence of acid ions, which in turn enhances their superacidity and activity [68,69]. The addition of molybdenum also triggers the formation of sulphides and facilitates the conversion of asphaltenes into oil products [70,71]. The addition of sulfate ions is primarily responsible for enhancing the dispersion of the catalyst, while the incorporation of acid ions led to the formation of magnetic pyrite with a particle size of merely 10 nm for the iron oxides. Studies have also highlighted the promotional relationship between highly dispersed catalysts and active hydrogen [72]. Notably, the fine powder particles of these catalysts are mobile during the liquefaction process, ensuring stability even without coal support. The development of new loaded catalysts may provide an effective solution to the problem. The crucial function of catalysts in coal liquefaction is evident. They facilitate the rate of reaction, influence the transfer pathway of hydrogen and the behaviour of the solvent as a hydrogen donor, and redistribute the total hydrogen consumption. The development of novel loaded catalysts, including the use of additives to alter the balance between cracking and hydrogenation, and the use of support materials beyond Al2O3, SiO2-Al2O3, mixed oxides, ion-exchanged oxides, and carbon. Carbon, as well as mixed oxides such as Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3, which are carrier substances with favorable activity and stability in the cracking reaction, is often ion-exchanged to provide additional acidic sites, thereby facilitating the cracking reaction. With regard to the hydrogenation reaction, the incorporation of select noble metals, including nickel (Ni), palladium (Pd), platinum (Pt), and rhodium (Rh), metal sulfides, accelerators (such as elements P and F), and inhibitors can serve to augment the hydrogenation activity. They may offer an effective solution to enhance the liquefaction process and its economics [73,74]. Highly dispersed novel loaded catalysts hold significant potential for further advancement in this field. 4 Catalysts for direct coal liquefaction 4.1 Iron catalysts From the early 20th century to the present, iron-based catalysts have undergone a progressive journey from initial exploration to industrial application, steadily enhancing their catalytic performance and environmental adaptability, thus emerging as a pivotal technology in this field. Iron-based catalysts, characterized by their efficiency and cost-effectiveness, have found extensive utilization in industrial production owing to their exceptional coal conversion, oil yield activity, reasonable price point, and single-use attributes [56,75,76]. The widespread availability of iron coupled with its environmentally benign nature not only renders iron catalysts resourceful and sustainable but also aligns them with the requisites of green development, thereby promoting clean coal utilization. With the escalating demand for coal liquefaction, research on iron catalysts has been further propelled [77,78]. The roles of iron-based catalysts in direct coal liquefaction generally involve catalyzing hydrogen transfer and breaking down complex coal macromolecules into smaller, more manageable molecules. The mechanisms by which iron catalysts enhance the liquefaction process include hydrogenation, hydrocracking, and hydrogenolysis. Iron facilitates the cleaving of C–C and C–O bonds in the coal structure, thereby promoting the breakdown of macromolecules. It also assists in the saturation of the resulting fragments with hydrogen, stabilizing them and preventing recondensation reactions. Iron-based catalysts are widely acknowledged and industrially employed as active metal catalysts in coal liquefaction processes, primarily due to their superior hydrogen molecule activation capability. This activation is crucial for facilitating the reaction between hydrogen and organic molecules present in coal, leading to its conversion. Both pyrite powder (Fe1 − x S) and synthesized α-FeOOH catalysts exhibit enhanced hydrogen transfer under H2S atmosphere, which plays a vital role in promoting the hydrocracking process of coal and improving the efficiency of product hydrogenation. While there is a risk of oxidative deactivation associated with this type of catalyst, this limitation can be effectively overcome in H2S atmospheres, thereby ensuring the stability and activity of the catalyst. Specifically, maintaining an excess amount of H2S along with achieving a S/Fe molar ratio of 2.0 optimizes both hydrogen utilization efficiency and catalytic performance during coal liquefaction [76]. Consequently, precise control over H2S concentration and S/Fe molar ratio significantly enhances both stability and catalytic efficiency throughout the coal liquefaction process. The industrially viable iron catalyst, pyrite powder, possesses advantageous properties such as its affordability and the absence of sulfur addition. This suitability was further confirmed in reaction systems involving anthracene (ANT) dehydrogenation, and THN under a hydrogen atmosphere for hydrogen supply [79]. The study elucidates the chemisorption and desorption behavior of hydrogen over pyrite (Fe1 − x S) catalysts. Dehydrogenation occurs on Fe1 − x S with or without anthracene in the system; however, when anthracene is present, hydrogen undergoes two transformations on the catalyst as direct H2 and anthracene-hydrogen compounds. Additionally, it was determined that the dehydrogenation reaction of Fe1 − x S in the anthracene system is limited by chemical equilibrium while measuring an enthalpy value of 117.6 kJ mol− 1 for system dehydrogenation. In the hydrogen supply system, after undergoing dehydrogenation in a specific setup, Fe1 − x S can be rehydrogenated within both H2 and H2 + THN systems; lower temperatures favor this rehydrogenation reaction. Especially in the H2 system, the temperature effect on the rehydrogenation reaction of Fe1 − x S is more pronounced (Fig. 5 b). Hydrogen transfer pathways on Fe1 − x S through dehydrogenation in the ANT system and rehydrogenation in the THN and H2 systems are further elucidated in Fig. 5(a). Stepwise hemolytic method gradually facilitates hydrogen transfer over Fe1 − x S catalysts to H2 and ANT in the gas phase. Among these pathways, active hydrogens generated from S–H bond cleavage reactions on the catalyst are more likely to combine with each other to produce hydrogen, potentially generating DHA radicals as intermediates that capture hydrogen from Fe1 − x S to generate DHA, thereby completing hydrogen transfer from Fe1 − x S to ANT and H2. In both the H2 and THN systems, sulfur exposed at the edge of the catalyst cluster undergoes gradual hydrogenation until reaching saturation point before being adsorbed again onto Fe1 − x S, thus accomplishing hydrogen transfer from both a hydrogen-donating solvent and H2 to the Fe1 − x S cluster. These findings not only confirm pyrite powder's catalytic efficiency in hydrogen transfer reactions but also provide a scientific basis for its application in coal liquefaction processes, further highlighting how optimizing catalyst performance by fine-tuning reaction conditions is crucial. Iron oxides and hydroxides exhibit excellent performance in activating hydrogen molecules, leading to their conversion into the active phase Fe1 − x S. Since catalysts' active sites are located on their surfaces, reducing the particle size of catalysts can significantly increase their specific surface area, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. For instance, the Fe2O3 catalyst effectively enhances direct liquefaction by facilitating molecular hydrogen activation in various hydrogen supply solvents. However, this catalyst exhibits relatively weak performance in activating solvent-to-solvent hydrogen and transferring hydrogen within the solvent. To address this issue, researchers successfully synthesized oleic acid-coated Fe3O4 nanocrystalline catalysts with a diameter of approximately 15 nm through thermal decomposition of iron oleate complexes. Direct liquefaction experiments demonstrated that the catalyst yielded 86.5% oil at a Fe content of 1.5 wt%, surpassing industrial-grade Fe3O4 powder with a Fe content of 3.0 wt%, indicating that the mass percentage of iron element also influences catalytic efficiency. Additionally, researchers pre-sulfurized γ-Fe2O3 catalysts using various liquid media including alkanes, aromatics, and heteroatomic compounds. Nitrogen-containing compounds were found to exert a significant negative impact on the hydrogenation activity of these catalysts as evidenced by naphthalene conversions ranging from only 2.5% to 15%. As depicted in Fig. 5(c), reduced catalytic activity is attributed to diminished S vacancies which serve as Lewis acid sites promoting hydrogenation reactions [80]. Therefore, by precisely modulating the S/Fe molar ratio of the catalyst, the generation of S vacancies and hence activated hydrogen reaction sites is increased as much as possible. The microstructure of iron oxide precursors is closely related to their catalytic performance. Therefore, the researchers synthesized carrierless and coal carrier iron oxide catalysts with gradient microstructures through precipitation-oxidation at lower temperatures. It was found that the carrier-free FeOOH precursors mainly consisted of γ-FeOOH or α-FeOOH crystalline phases, which have a larger specific surface area, higher humidity, and more reactive oxygen species due to their easy conversion into fine magnetic pyrite. Notably, there was a linear relationship between the liquefied oil yield and the grain size of fine magnetic pyrite, which is closely associated with the formation of the crystalline phase in the catalyst precursor [81]. Furthermore, the carrier coal has been demonstrated to effectively inhibit the secondary polymerization and particle size change of iron oxides, thereby effectively dispersing the activity of precursors and markedly enhancing the catalytic activity. Kaneko conducted liquefaction experiments with Yallourn coal with the objective of conducting a systematic investigation into the transformation process of iron-based catalysts (including α-FeOOH, γ-FeOOH, hydrated iron, limonite, and natural pyrite) into the active phase magnetic pyrite (Fe1 − x S) [82]. It was determined that hydrated iron and FeOOH exhibited the lowest transformation temperature, at 250 °C, while pyrite (FeS2) demonstrated the highest transformation temperature, at 350 °C. Concurrently, the grain size of magnetopyrite is observed to increase in conjunction with an elevation in reaction temperature. The sequence of growth for magnetopyrite crystals is as follows: γ-FeOOH < limonite, α-FeOOH, iron hydrate < pyrite (FeS2). The addition of sulfur can inhibit the crystal growth of magnetopyrite by controlling its sulfur-rich structure. The presence of H2S, however, has a different effect. Due to its ability to transform into magnetopyrite with a smaller grain size, γ-FeOOH exhibits superior catalytic activity in the coal liquefaction process (Fig. 6 c) [81]. To enhance the catalytic efficiency and oil yield, the researchers prepared β-FeOOH nanoparticle catalysts (denoted as β-FeOOH@C) loaded on coal by solid-phase in situ impregnation (Fig. 6a). The β-FeOOH catalyst was observed to possess a bulk structure comprising particles with a diameter range of 10–50 nm. Similarly, β-FeOOH@C exhibited an irregular bulk structure with the same morphology and particle size, but the particle size was smaller than that of the original coal. This suggests that the catalyst solids facilitated the return of the original coal particles under grinding action and that β-FeOOH was uniformly loaded on the coal particles in situ. Furthermore, β-FeOOH@C demonstrated enhanced catalytic efficacy, with an increase in coal conversion and oil yield of 2.92% and 12.38%, respectively (Fig. 6b). To summarize, both in-situ loading and enhanced dispersion of catalyst particles during direct liquefaction are advantageous for enhancing the pyrolysis activity of coal while also promoting miniaturization of magnetopyrite crystals and increasing liquefaction oil production rate [83]. Iron-based catalysts, particularly iron sulphide, exhibit distinctive catalytic activity in hydro-liquefaction processes. Pyrite powder serves as a cost-effective alternative due to its affordability and lack of requirement for additional sulphurisation. Moreover, iron oxides and hydroxides possess favorable catalytic properties with a tendency towards conversion into the active phase Fe1 − x S [78]. The performance of the catalyst heavily relies on its microstructure, highlighting intricate design intricacies. Magnetic pyrite plays a crucial role as an active phase sourced from diverse precursors such as red mud, bauxite slag obtained during alumina separation process, along with various types of iron ores [75]. The interconversion process involving different forms of iron sulfides represents both complexity and significance within hydro-liquefaction [77,78]. Furthermore, the extent to which FeS2 and FeS undergo sulfidation significantly influences the exhibited catalytic activity by Fe1 − x S. Additionally, particle size also exerts a significant effect on catalyst performance. 4.2 Solid acid catalysts Solid acid catalysts play a pivotal role in the direct liquefaction of coal [84,85]. These catalysts are characterized by their ability to donate protons or accept electrons during coal liquefaction reactions, encompassing both Bronsted and Lewis acids. Not only do solid acid catalysts exhibit exceptional catalytic activity, promoting coal conversion and enhancing product selectivity under mild conditions of temperature and pressure, but certain catalysts can also be regenerated, thereby reducing both consumption and disposal costs [86]. Furthermore, these catalysts demonstrate remarkable resistance to contamination by impurities and potentially toxic substances, ensuring sustained catalytic activity over prolonged periods. By precisely tailoring the acidity and pore structure of solid acid catalysts, we can effectively control the selectivity and distribution of products in coal liquefaction reactions for optimal industrial applications [85,87,88]. In the direct liquefaction of coal, solid acid catalysts are introduced, particularly non-ferrous metal halides like zinc and tin (e.g., ZnCl2, SnCl2), which are extensively utilized due to their high cracking capacity [89,90]. However, these catalysts exhibit significant corrosiveness towards the equipment employed in the liquefaction unit. By investigating the role of SnCl2 in the coal liquefaction process, it was discovered that the formation of Sn powder within pure SnCl2 melt contributes to efficient hydrogen distribution during early stages of liquefaction and enhances coal reactivity with SnCl2. Furthermore, it was observed that prolonging reaction time under 10 wt% ZnCl2 catalysis resulted in increased H2S yield, saturation of aromatic rings and contributed to naphthenic product decomposition as well as asphaltene dealkylation. Subsequently, products containing naphthenes undergo mild decomposition while asphaltenes experience significant dealkylation reactions. With further increase in catalyst amount, it was determined that at 400 °C carbon–carbon bond cleavage leads to depolymerization along with substantial decomposition of aromatic nuclei. Thus, acidic catalytic systems typically involve bond breaking within coal structural units and removal of functional groups such as phenolic hydroxyls attached to aromatic rings during liquefaction reaction; thereby revealing a complex mechanism underlying catalyst action in coal liquefaction. The SO4 2 −/ZrO2 solid acid catalyst exhibits dual functionality in terms of pyrolysis and hydrogenation [84,91]. In our study on Shenhua Coal Liquefaction Kinetics, we observed that the pre-asphaltenes and asphaltenes generated through direct liquefaction can be converted into hydrocarbon products via subsequent hydrocracking [84]. The model-calculated liquefaction conversions were in good agreement with experimental data, demonstrating that the acidic properties of the catalyst effectively lowered the activation energy of pyrolysis reactions while its exceptional hydrogenation activity stabilized carbon ion intermediates. As a result, higher yields of oil and gas as well as coal liquefaction conversions were achieved. However, it should be noted that this catalyst undergoes significant degradation reactions at elevated temperatures leading to hydrocarbon conversion into asphaltenes and condensation of pre-asphaltenes and asphaltenes into coke. In order to thoroughly investigate the performance of solid acid catalysts in the coal liquefaction process, the researchers initially examined the utilization of four solid acid catalysts (TFMSA/ZrO2, TFMSA/ZSM-5, TFMSA/Al2O3, and TFMSA/SiO2) in sub-bituminous coal liquefaction from Hefeng, Xinjiang [85]. By analyzing the pyrolysis kinetics of these four residues from coal liquefaction (R-ZrO2, R-ZSM-5, R-Al2O3, and R-SiO2) using the Coast-Redfern method, it was observed that TFMSA/ZrO2 demonstrated superior catalytic activity with a coal conversion rate of 84.20% and an oil production rate of 67.16%. Furthermore, its liquefied residue (R-ZrO2) exhibited a significantly lower tertiary activation energy (21.514 kJ mol−1) compared to other residues after TFMSA/ZrO2-catalyzed liquefaction. This suggests that the residue was more easily decomposed following TFMSA/ZrO2 catalysis. Additionally, due to smoother liquefaction processes and fewer thermal polymerization reactions at high temperatures, smaller grain-sized residues were generated which are more readily decomposable. Based on these findings, the study further elucidated the significant enhancement of trifluoromethanesulfonic acid (TFMSA) in coal liquefaction reactions. TFMSA/ATA solid super acid catalysts were prepared by impregnating TFMSA onto acid-treated attapulgite (ATA), which were subsequently employed in hydro-liquefaction experiments using lignite coal from Ingmar Tip, Xinjiang [92]. The experimental results demonstrated that the TFMSA/ATA super acid catalyst exhibited exceptional catalytic activity towards both residue and light residue fractions during catalytic hydroextraction. By utilizing a density difference method, effective separation of inorganic minerals from extraction residues was achieved, leading to a significant increase in soluble fraction yield. This effect can be attributed to the strong acidity of the TFMSA/ATA catalyst, facilitating H+ release during the reaction and enabling its interaction with oxygen atoms within light component residues, thereby exhibiting remarkable catalytic activity (Fig. 7 c–e). Finally, additional catalytic hydrogenation conversion experiments were conducted on two lignite extraction residues using another solid super acid catalyst known as TFMSA/MPZCA (MPZCA: mesoporous zirconia-coated attapulgite). The experimental results demonstrated that the H+ released by the catalyst during the reaction interacted with the oxygen atoms of the volatile fraction of coal, playing a pivotal role in the formation of soluble fractions, particularly aromatic hydrocarbons. Fig. 7(a) clearly illustrates the mechanism of H+ release in ultra-strong solid acid catalyst TFMSA, where H+ primarily attacks oxygen atoms, thereby inducing hydrocracking reactions of OBMDB or BOB [93]. In the case of DNM, hydrocracking is achieved through incorporation of H+ into carbon atoms within DNM molecules. Considering that electronegativity (EN) values for oxygen atoms in OBMDB and BOB are significantly higher than those for homocarbon atoms in DNM, H+ exhibits a greater tendency to bind with oxygen atoms in DNM rather than homocarbon atoms. This disparity leads to higher hydrocracking reactivity for OBMDB compared to BOB. During hydrocracking, protonated OBMDB tends to decompose into benzyl alcohol (PM) and PhCH2+, while BOB predominantly produces toluene and phenol as products from its hydrocracking host. For DNM, the addition of H+ results in homocarbon protonation which subsequently promotes decomposition into naphthalene and naphthalene-1-methyl (NM), yielding both products at similar levels. Fig. 7(b) further elucidates potential reaction mechanisms whereby H+ released from solid acid catalysts attacks oxygen atoms within macromolecular components. The utilization of various solid acid catalysts, including zinc, tin halide, SO4 2 −/ZrO2, TFMSA/ZrO2, etc., has been demonstrated to effectively facilitate coal conversion at low temperatures and pressures while precisely controlling product distributions through modulation of catalyst properties such as acidity and pore structure. These catalysts exhibit remarkable capabilities in hydrogen distribution, aromatic ring cleavage, naphthenic product decomposition, and asphaltene dealkylation during the liquefaction process, thereby enhancing oil and gas production rates as well as coal liquefaction conversion. Nevertheless, concerns remain regarding catalyst corrosion and degradation reactions at high temperatures along with selectivity issues under specific catalytic regimes. Notably, the strong acidity of TFMSA significantly promotes catalytic hydrocracking reactions by increasing the yield of soluble fractions and facilitating aromatics formation. In summary, the application of solid acid catalysts in coal liquefaction demonstrates notable characteristics including high catalytic activity efficiency, adjustable product selectivity controlability for economic recycling purposes, and sensitive to reaction conditions, collectively determining their pivotal role in the coal liquefaction process. 4.3 Mo, Co, Ni catalysts Non-precious metal catalysts, such as Mo, Co, and Ni, have been extensively investigated and utilized as active components in hydrogenation catalysts due to their cost-effectiveness, robust stability, resistance to sulphur and nitrogen species, and exceptional catalytic properties. However, these catalysts exhibit relatively low hydrogenation activity and often necessitate harsher reaction conditions for operation. This not only escalates the operational expenses but also restricts their broad applicability [94,95]. To enhance catalytic efficacy, these active elements are typically present in the form of oxides or sulphides or through combinations of two or more elements to achieve a synergistic catalytic effect that optimizes overall performance. The MoS2 catalyst has been demonstrated to enhance DCL performance by facilitating the activation of hydrogen molecules, as well as solvents and transferred hydrogen. In contrast, the Fe2O3 catalyst primarily promotes hydrogen molecule activation, thereby improving liquefaction performance (Fig. 8 a and b) [96]. The catalyst precursor Mo(CO)6 has the ability to form active catalysts with well-defined structures without the need for liquid additives or special impregnation processes. In an H2S atmosphere, the decomposition of Mo(CO)6 is facilitated, thereby promoting coal liquefaction and the formation of a reactive phase containing MoS2. Conversely, under sulfur-free conditions, the carbide derived from Mo(CO)6 exhibits higher methanation activity compared to the sulfide phase [97]. The pressure and temperature data obtained from microthermal autoclave experiments provided valuable insights into changes in gas volumes within the experimental system. These data served as a basis for selecting a slow heating regime that was crucial for distinguishing between catalyst activity and catalyst activation effects. The utilization of dispersed MoS2 catalysts with ammonium tetrathiomolybdate (ATTM) as a precursor under solvent-free liquefaction at 350 °C, in conjunction with the addition of an appropriate quantity of water, has been demonstrated to significantly enhance the conversion of sub-bituminous coal [98]. The preparation of MoS2 catalysts with high surface area and good dispersion can be achieved through the use of a moderate amount of water in a temperature range of 325–375 °C. Furthermore, this process is not reliant on hydrogen donor or non-donor solvents. However, temperatures exceeding 400 °C have shown that the addition of water negatively impacts the catalytic conversion of coal. Based on these findings, we propose a new process flow involving the use of a dispersed Mo catalyst precursor at temperatures between 325 and 375 °C, followed by programmed temperature-raising liquefaction through the addition of an appropriate amount of water in the first stage. Subsequently, the second stage dehydration reaction is carried out at temperatures between 400 and 425 °C under H2 pressure. This innovative process opens up promising avenues for further research into catalytic conversion methods for coal-to-liquid fuels and chemical feedstocks. The hydrogenation activity of MoS2 catalysts for naphthalene and tetrahydronaphthalene was significantly higher than that of Fe2O3 catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 8(c and d). Theoretical calculations of the thermodynamic properties at 435 °C indicated that the respective theoretical conversions for naphthalene and tetrahydronaphthalene were 67% and 80%. These values surpass the actual conversions, suggesting potential enhancements in catalyst design and optimization. The outcomes for the two hydrogen-supplying solvents are primarily influenced by different atmospheric conditions (e.g., an H2 atmosphere favors naphthalene hydrogenation). It can be observed that naphthalene hydrogenation allows for higher rates of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation, which aligns with radical generation rate. Fig. 8(e) illustrates the effect of single-occupancy molecular orbital on tetrahydronaphthalene, where the transition metal attracts s-bonded electronic orbitals formed by dehydrogenation active sites C and H. This leads to a reduction in electron cloud density, weakening interactions between C and H, resulting in lowered bonding order and BDEs. The findings suggest that coal direct liquefaction catalyst configuration should consider equilibrium between hydrogen supply and other factors. According to the hydrogen transfer theory, Fe-Mo composite catalyst is more conducive to activating the hydrogen source, thereby optimizing DCL performance. The replacement of cobalt in hydrogen transfer has been demonstrated to have a significant impact on the liquefaction process of low-rank coals. A comparison between the liquefaction effects of demineralized coal or demineralized coal mixed with complexes ((C5H5)2CO or CO2(CO)8) and cobalt-exchanged coal reveals that the former can effectively disperse into coal macromolecules containing carboxyl groups, thereby enhancing the catalytic effect of dispersed cobalt, improving hydrogen mobility in solvents, and significantly enhancing quality. Compared to composite additive coal, the residual rate of cobalt-exchanged coal after liquefaction is only 0.3%, demonstrating its high efficiency and environmental benefits [99]. The Co/SiO2/Fe3O4 and Ni/TiO2 catalysts were specifically designed for utilization with both sulphur-containing and non-sulphur-containing coals. Both catalysts can be easily recovered through magnetic gradient, thereby enhancing their recyclability efficiency. Direct liquefaction of aliphatic-rich “bitumen-rich” lignite oil achieved a maximum yield of 71 wt% when employing a small quantity of nano Co/SiO2 or Co/SiO2/Fe3O4 catalysts, resulting in further improvement in oil quality [100]. Conversely, the hydrothermal carbonisation (HTC) of biomass using the novel Ni/TiO2 catalyst yielded a high oil yield of 42 wt% during direct liquefaction of biocoal. This innovative catalyst exhibits significant potential for environmental protection. In order to enhance the economic viability of direct coal liquefaction, it is imperative to develop catalysts with enhanced sustainability and activity to mitigate the significant cost impact of high hydrogen pressure. However, an increase in catalyst activity is typically accompanied by a rise in the cost and activity of the metals used. It is therefore reasonable to conclude that the use of highly dispersed forms of catalysts represents a viable strategy. However, loaded catalysts, which are capable of achieving high dispersion of metals, are not widely employed in the primary liquefaction stage of coal due to difficulties associated with efficient penetration into coal fragments' pore structure. To overcome these challenges, researchers have explored optimizing catalytic performance by tuning morphology and composition. For instance, Mo(CO)6 as a catalyst precursor can form structures such as MoS2 and carbide phases with high activity when coexisting with coal under specific conditions including H2S presence. In terms of catalyst design, this study emphasizes the importance of maintaining a balance between hydrogen supply and the utilization of diverse coal characteristics through composite and tailor-made catalysts. Moreover, it suggests that optimizing the microstructure and active sites of catalysts can enhance the economic and environmental sustainability of direct liquefaction. Therefore, non-precious metal catalysts containing molybdenum, cobalt, and nickel exhibit significant potential for applications such as direct coal liquefaction and biomass conversion. However, further research is necessary to address existing challenges related to catalyst activity and stability while developing novel catalysts that facilitate more efficient and cost-effective energy conversion processes. 4.4 Composite catalysts The shift from investigating individual metal elements in oxidation and sulphide states to utilizing multi-component catalysts that harness the synergistic effects of diverse elements aims to overcome the limitations of single catalysts. Subdividing the catalyst into smaller particles and dispersing them uniformly in the coal slurry can significantly enhance its efficiency [101]. Rational design and combination of different catalysts can facilitate higher reaction rates, product selectivity, and longer catalyst life. In certain cases, multiple catalysts are necessary for effective catalysis. The coordination environment and ratio of the catalysts can be precisely adjusted to enhance reaction selectivity. Two-component combinations such as Co-Mo and Ni-Mo are commonly used to optimize hydrogenation activity; however, concerns remain regarding their extent of sulphation due to SH acting as a free radical chain transfer agent. Other metal-based composites classified as composite catalysts are also utilized [102]. The US H-Coal process uses Ni-Mo/Al2O3 and Co-Mo/Al2O3 as catalysts [103]. The process operates at a temperature of 723 K and a hydrogen pressure of 20 MPa. Through gravity separation, spent catalyst particles can be removed from the boiling bed reactor and recycled back into the process. This approach considers both catalyst dispersion and rational recycling, reducing the need for new catalysts. In a study on asphaltene preparation from Red Willow Grove coal, researchers employed Ni-Co-Mo, Co-Mo, and Fe2O3 catalysts in a multi-stage deep liquefaction process [104]. The transformation of oxidized structures was investigated through analysis of individual component yields using ultimate analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The findings demonstrated that within the temperature range of 440–480 °C, the Ni-Co-Mo catalyst exhibited robust catalytic efficacy for asphaltene conversion while significantly enhancing oil yield. Furthermore, the Ni-Co-Mo catalysts exhibited the ability to reduce the oxygen content of asphaltenes and increase the H/C ratio. A significant correlation was observed between these modifications and the oil yield. The residual organic oxygen in asphaltene after liquefaction mainly exists in the forms of C–O, C–O, and COO. The Ni–Co–Mo catalyst can catalyze the cleavage of CO bonds, leading to the formation of numerous C–O bonds. This subsequently enhances the oil yield. The remaining asphaltene contains approximately 34% of stable aromatic ether structures primarily composed of C–O bonds that are resistant to hydrocracking reactions. It is evident that synergistic effects resulting from multiple metal elements have significantly improved catalytic performance. The total yield of soluble products obtained from catalytic hydroconversion of long-flame coal from Hang Lai Wan was 33.7%, which significantly exceeded that achieved by non-catalytic hydroconversion (10.5%) (Fig. 9 a). In the former process, magnetic copper ferrite nanoparticles (CuFe2O4) were employed as catalysts at a temperature of 300 °C and an initial hydrogen pressure of 1 MPa [105]. The CuFe2O4 catalyst exhibits the ability to activate H2, forming diatomic active hydrogen (H…H), and decompose H…H into mobile H+ and immobile H−. Subsequently, the released H+ ions bind to oxygen atoms (OAs) in >C–O– bridge bonds, breaking these bonds and generating soluble products (Fig. 9b). Fig. 9(c) illustrates similar distributions of O1-O4 species for both SPNCHC (non-catalytic hydrotransformation soluble fraction) and SPCHC (catalytic hydrotransformation soluble fraction). However, in SPCHC, the O1-O4 species shifted towards lower double bond equivalent (DBE) values and carbon numbers (CN). Amongst the O1 species, those with DBE <4 are likely furans while compounds with DBE of 4, 7, or 10 are possibly benzenes, naphthalenes, anthracenes, or benzanthracenes containing an oxygen-containing group such as a hydroxyl or ether bond in their side chains. Additionally, abundant O1 species with DBE of 5 and 6 can be identified in SPCHC which may correspond to indole alcohols and benzofurans respectively. Regarding the O2 species present in both fractions; those with DBE of <4 could be fatty acids whereas compounds with DBE of 4, 7, or10 might represent benzene, naphthalene, and anthracene or benzanthracene derivatives possessing two oxygen-containing groups like hydroxyl or ether bonds within their side chains. Additionally, SPCHC exhibits a significant abundance of O1 species with DBE of 5 and 6, which are likely to be indole alcohols and benzofurans. Among the O2 species, those with a DBE of <4 are presumed to be fatty acids, while compounds with a DBE of 4, 7, or 10 are expected to be benzene, naphthalene, and anthracene or benzanthracene derivatives containing two oxygen-containing groups (hydroxyl or ether bonds) in the side chain. Notably, naphthoic acid with DBE of 8 and benzoic acid with DBE of 5 appear as the most abundant O2 species in SPNCHC and SPCHC respectively. These findings demonstrate that CuFe2O4 effectively disrupts >C–O– BBs (bridged bonds) present in Hanglaiwan long-flame coal by converting insoluble organic macromolecules into soluble organic macromolecules, thereby facilitating the clean conversion process. In comparison to single catalysts, composite catalysts exhibit enhanced catalytic performance, elevated reaction rates, improved product selectivity, and extended catalyst lifespans. By precisely adjusting the ratio and coordination environment of the various catalysts, it is possible to achieve precise control over the reaction, thereby improving its selectivity. Typical two-component catalysts such as Co-Mo or Ni-Mo display distinct metal hydrogenation activities with Ni-Mo exhibiting higher activity than Co-Mo. The composite catalysts demonstrate remarkable efficacy in coal liquefaction processes, leading to a significant increase in oil yield, reduction in asphaltene oxygen content, and enhancement of H/C ratio. These changes show a strong correlation with oil yield. Residual organic oxygen in asphaltene after liquefaction primarily exists as CO, C–O, and COO forms. The composite catalyst can effectively catalyze the fracture of CO bonds and promote substantial formation of C–O bonds which further enhances oil yield. Through continuous exploration and optimization efforts, researchers have successfully improved the efficiency and economy of coal liquefaction by progressing from single-metal catalysts to multi-metal composite ones followed by microstructure adjustments of the catalysts themselves. These advancements not only result in the increased oil yield but also enable cleaner conversion and utilization of coal. 4.5 Other catalysts In the direct coal liquefaction process, the selection of an appropriate catalyst is crucial for optimizing reaction efficiency and ensuring high-quality product outcomes. Metal oxides and sulphides are commonly employed as catalysts due to their exceptional activity in hydrogenation processes and facilitation of gaseous hydrogen transfer to carbonaceous substrates. Conventional iron-based catalysts, such as alumina, zeolite, or activated carbon, are frequently utilized as carriers in direct coal liquefaction. Moreover, researchers have introduced a second metal (e.g., nickel, cobalt, or molybdenum) as a promoter or explored composite systems comprising multiple catalysts to enhance catalytic efficacy. Despite the wide range of technologies used in liquefaction catalyst production, ongoing research focuses on developing novel catalysts with superior activity, selectivity, cost-effectiveness, and environmental compatibility. In studies investigating the oxidation treatment of coke in Colombia, researchers have identified that the utilization of dilute oxygen combined with varying concentrations of nitric acid for coke oxidation leads to the formation of surfaces abundant in phenolic and lactone oxygenated groups. This phenomenon has been observed to enhance the dispersion of the active phase, thereby elevating catalyst performance [106]. Furthermore, this treatment not only elucidated the role played by different oxidation treatments in modulating both active phase dispersion and catalyst pore structure but also achieved marginal enhancements in conversion and oil production through functionalized coke catalyst loading. Consequently, this improvement resulted in reduced hydrogen consumption, decreased gas and asphaltene production, as well as increased oil production, leading to a reduction in liquefaction costs. Highly dispersed catalysts often play a crucial role in the liquefaction process [107]. Three highly dispersed catalyst precursors, namely Fe(CO)5-S, Mo(CO)6-S, and Ru3 (CO)12, activate hydrogen. Kinetic modeling has demonstrated that the amount of hydrogen transferred from the gas phase is significantly greater than that transferred from tetrahydronaphthalene during the hydroliquefaction of various coals. This phenomenon indicates direct hydrogen transfer from the gas phase to coal fragmentation radicals, which can potentially influence the early stages of liquefaction reaction. Moreover, this trend is supported by the catalytic reaction of phenyl ethers mediated by Mo and Ru catalysts. The primary role of catalysts in the hydroliquefaction of coal in tetrahydronaphthalene is to facilitate the transfer of molecular hydrogen into the thermally decomposed coal mass, rather than promoting the re-hydrogenation of naphthalene to tetrahydronaphthalene. In conclusion, these aforementioned studies hold significant implications for comprehending the mechanism of catalyst action in coal liquefaction, considering factors such as sulphidation process, high dispersion, multifunctionality of catalysts, and strong carrier interaction. In relation to iron-based catalysts, studies have demonstrated that magnetic pyrite is the active substance produced during liquefaction. Due to their advantageous characteristics such as high activity, low cost, and absence of environmental pollution, iron-based catalysts have been employed in the coal liquefaction project of the Shenhua Group. Additionally, this paper provides an extensive account of solid acid catalysts, molybdenum-cobalt–nickel-based catalysts, composite catalysts, and other types of catalysts used in coal liquefaction. It elucidates the potential performance of each catalyst despite their limited industrial-scale application thus far. Notably, studying catalysts is particularly important in low-order coal liquefaction as it requires enhanced activity and selectivity to cope with complex reaction conditions. The process of coal liquefaction is a highly intricate chemical process that necessitates the utilization of exceptionally efficient catalysts to facilitate the reaction. Despite the development of numerous catalysts, their implementation in industrial settings remains challenging due to inherent difficulties associated with dispersion during the reaction phase, regeneration and recycling rates, as well as economic considerations. The catalysts currently employed in coal liquefaction continue to pose several challenges (Fig. 10 ). (1) The activity and selectivity of catalysts in coal liquefaction represent a significant area of interest, encompassing the cleavage and hydrocracking of hydrogenated arylalkyl bonds within aromatic ring macromolecules and radicals present in coal, as well as the formation of methylene bridges between arylalkyl rings and alkanes. Additionally, it involves the removal of hydrogen from heteroatoms such as oxygen, sulfur, and nitrogen. Furthermore, crucial factors include the composition, crystal structure, surface acidity and alkalinity, surface area, and pore structure of the catalyst. Besides high activity and selectivity requirements for catalysts, consideration must also be given to competing reactions among various reactive species present in coal liquids while acknowledging the role played by the catalyst in facilitating these diverse reactions. (2) The stability and longevity of catalysts are crucial for maintaining efficient catalytic performance over extended periods under the harsh conditions characteristic of coal liquefaction, which involve elevated temperatures, high pressures, and the presence of corrosive substances. Contamination and corrosion by minerals, impurities, and carbon deposits present in coal can lead to a decline in catalyst activity and selectivity. (3) The development of efficient catalyst regeneration technologies, as well as the realization of catalyst recycling, poses a significant challenge. As the liquefaction reaction progresses, the catalyst experiences deactivation, necessitating either regeneration or replacement. However, the presence of minerals and organic matter in coal can lead to complex formation with the catalyst, thereby complicating its separation and recovery process. Therefore, it is necessary to develop efficient and suitable catalyst regeneration or recycling technology. (4) The optimization of coal liquefaction catalysts through preparation and process engineering represents a crucial avenue for enhancing catalytic performance and reducing costs. It is imperative to develop appropriate methods for synthesizing catalysts with specific structures and compositions, as well as accurately characterizing their physical and chemical properties. In addition to the active components, carrier materials, and preparation techniques employed in catalyst synthesis, it is essential to optimize the coal liquefaction process parameters such as temperature, pressure, and solvent ratio in order to achieve optimal catalytic efficiency. (5) The coal liquefaction process is an energy conversion mechanism, the economic feasibility of which relies on the effectiveness of catalysts employed. It is crucial to develop cost-efficient and high-performance catalysts to enhance the economic viability and reduce costs associated with coal liquefaction. The primary objective of coal liquefaction is to achieve the efficient, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly utilization of coal resources, reducing reliance on conventional petroleum resources and mitigating environmental contamination associated with coal combustion. Through an analysis of the direct liquefaction mechanism of coal and catalyst action principles, it can be concluded that uncovering and optimizing the synergistic interaction between solvents and catalysts is important for facilitating hydrogen supply and improving liquid yields. Future research will focus on developing catalysts for promoting such dissociations and studying active hydrogen generation behavior on these catalysts, as well as preparing highly dispersible catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Coal direct liquefaction technology is a crucial contemporary coal chemical technology for efficient and clean use of coal resources. The development of direct coal liquefaction technology and the promotion of alternative energy sources are important measures to guarantee energy security and economic security. However, several challenges need to be addressed, including low conversion rate, inadequate oil yield, significant coking, demanding reaction conditions, and high energy consumption. Extensive research has been conducted on these issues, but further exploration is required in certain aspects such as pyrolysis of macromolecules during the liquefaction process, hydrogen activation, catalysts’ performance and stability, solvent hydrogenation, as well as interactions between free radicals to understand their mechanisms better. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the design strategy for efficient catalysts in coal liquefaction, encompassing the mechanism of coal liquefaction, catalyst construction, and enhancement of catalytic conversion efficiency. It serves as a comprehensive guide for further research endeavors. Firstly, it systematically summarizes the conversion mechanism of direct coal liquefaction, provides detailed descriptions of various catalyst design strategies, and especially outlines the catalytic mechanism. Furthermore, it addresses the challenges and prospects associated with constructing efficient catalysts for direct coal liquefaction based on an understanding of their action mechanisms.
